awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Regulation and Function of Imprinted Gene Expression in Seeds
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant seeds are an important part of the human diet, and they also play a vital role in plant reproduction.  However, the precise molecular details of how seeds develop and grow are not well understood.  The goal of this project is to advance our understanding of seed development, which in turn could have a beneficial outcome for production of seeds as a nutritious food source.  The project will also provide interdisciplinary education and training in genetics, genomics, bioinformatics, and molecular biology for high school teachers, undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows.  High school science teachers will spend two summers in the laboratory, participating directly in research activities and developing inquiry-based learning modules related to plant biology research, which they will bring back to their classrooms. This partnership will establish long-term connections to teachers to increase their students' ability to analyze quantitative information and generate knowledge from scientific exploration. 

Seed development in flowering plants is regulated, in part, by genes that are imprinted.  Gene imprinting is an epigenetic phenomenon whereby alleles of genes are differentially expressed depending on whether they are inherited from the male or female parent.  To understand and manipulate seed biology to beneficial effect requires deciphering the regulation and function of imprinted gene expression. Recent studies have created catalogues of imprinted genes in diverse plant species, and have yielded important insights about the extent of imprinting and the types of genes subject to imprinted expression. However, it remains unclear whether all imprinting is functional, or whether some instances of imprinting are bystander events due to genome-wide epigenetic reprogramming processes. The major aims of this research project are to comprehensively evaluate the function of imprinted genes in seed development, to test whether pure epigenetic variation is sufficient to induce imprinting variation, and to understand the gene networks that regulate imprinting by taking advantage of natural variation in imprinting phenotypes. This research will have substantial outcomes in further determining the functional consequences of imprinting and in understanding epigenetic mechanisms that regulate imprinted expression, increasing our understanding of seed biology and role of natural variation in these processes. Finally, tools to precisely engineer the DNA methylome in a sequence specific manner will be developed, allowing a direct test of whether specific DNA methylation patterns are necessary and sufficient for imprinted expression. These tools have the potential to be functional in other plant and animal species.

por.por_cntn:
Plant seeds are the basis of all agriculture and are fundamental to human life and the health of the planet. The goal of this project was to decipher the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms that regulate the development of viable seeds. Specifically, the research focused on the regulation and function of imprinted gene expression in seeds.

Although most organisms inherit one copy of every gene from each of their parents, these copies are not always interpreted by the cell in same manner. For a few hundred genes, only the copy inherited from the mother is active, and for another set of genes only the copy inherited from the father is active. This is referred to as gene imprinting, and is controlled by marks that distinguish maternal and paternal copies of genes. Imprinting exists in mammals and flowering plants. In flowering plants, imprinting occurs in a seed tissue called the endosperm. The endosperm is analogous to the mammalian placenta and mediates nutrient transfer from the maternal parent to the developing plant embryo. Functional endosperm is necessary for the development of viable seeds.

Imprinting offers an excellent case study for understanding epigenetic mechanisms of gene regulation. Epigenetics refers to heritable information that is not encoded in the DNA itself. In this project we addressed the dynamics of imprinting across multiple scales, from single cells to cross-species comparisons, and identified new mechanisms regulating the interaction of maternal and paternal genomes in offspring. Research was primarily focused on the plant model organism Arabidopsis thaliana. Several key findings emerged. Through targeted manipulation of epigenetic state, we demonstrated that epigenetic variation is sufficient to explain imprinting variation within a species. We further concluded that the impact of naturally-occurring epialleles (copies of genes with differences in epigenetic state) is likely to be most pronounced in seeds, a tissue where epigenetic dynamics are an essential part of development. This research also showed that changing imprinting status can alter the timing of endosperm development, leading to differences in seed size. Using single-cell approaches, we discovered new endosperm cell types and showed that imprinting is spatially and temporally heterogeneous in endosperm. Our efforts to understand the function of the imprinted gene RNA Pol IV provided new insight into how maternally and paternally inherited genomes interact in the endosperm after fertilization. RNA Pol IV is part of a pathway that generates small non-coding RNAs that ultimately direct epigenetic modifications. We discovered that the RNA Pol IV-small RNA pathway mediates the expression level of imprinted genes and hundreds of other genes throughout the genome. These findings revealed that small RNAs actively regulate the relative expression of maternal and paternal copies of genes in endosperm. Moreover, disrupting genes in this pathway is sufficient to bypass the normal requirements for maternal and paternal genomes in endosperm. These discoveries highlight the active tug-of-war between maternal and paternal genomes with regard to transcriptional outcomes in endosperm. Together, this research has made fundamental contributions to the understanding of seed biology.

This project provided multiple opportunities for training of graduate students, postdoctoral associates, undergraduates, and high school teachers. Researchers gained skills in genomics, genetics, molecular biology, and computational biology. Public high school teachers participated in laboratory research and learned how to develop plant science experiments for their classrooms, further expanding the impact of the research program.
